quotes.quote: To develop the Vintage 2024 population estimates and to better reflect current trends and potentially underrepresented populations, the Census Bureau used newly available administrative data to adjust the usually survey-based estimates of foreign-born immigration.
quotes.context: Opening statement in blog post explaining Vintage 2024 methodology changes
quotes.relevance: Documents the introduction of DHS administrative data as a new methodology component in Vintage 2024

quotes.quote: Data from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is used to make an estimate of the immigration of humanitarian migrants. In recent years the size of this group has increased significantly, and the traditional data sources have not been able to keep up.
quotes.context: Explanation of why methodology change was needed
quotes.relevance: Identifies DHS as the new administrative data source and explains the limitation of traditional ACS-based methods

quotes.quote: The adjustment for humanitarian migrants was applied to the national total and then distributed down to states and counties using the Census Bureau's usual method. As a result, the state and county estimates are also impacted by the adjustment.
quotes.context: Explanation of how national adjustment affects state estimates
quotes.relevance: Documents the state-level impact of national methodology change

quotes.quote: Since this adjustment was made to account for the under-sampling of humanitarian migrants in the ACS, this approach likely does not accurately reflect the distribution of these humanitarian migrants across states.
quotes.context: Census Bureau acknowledging limitation of state-level allocation
quotes.relevance: Critical admission that state-level estimates carry acknowledged uncertainty in geographic allocation

quotes.quote: The Census Bureau is currently researching the best way to distribute this nationwide international migration adjustment to states and counties.
quotes.context: Statement about ongoing research to improve methodology
quotes.relevance: Indicates that state-level allocation methodology is actively being reconsidered

quotes.quote: Due to periodic methodological updates, such as this year's immigration adjustment, year-to-year comparisons in the estimates should only be done within the same vintage.
quotes.context: Guidance to data users about vintage comparability
quotes.relevance: Explicit warning against comparing data across vintages - central to our research question

quotes.quote: The term 'vintage' denotes estimates created with a consistent population starting point and methodology.
quotes.context: Definition of vintage in Census Bureau methodology documentation
quotes.relevance: Establishes that each vintage represents a methodologically distinct series

quotes.quote: The release of a new vintage supersedes any previous estimates series because the new series incorporates the most up-to-date data and methodological improvements.
quotes.context: Census Bureau policy on vintage updates
quotes.relevance: Documents the replacement rather than supplementary nature of new vintages

quotes.quote: Data from separate vintages should not be combined.
quotes.context: Direct guidance on vintage combination
quotes.relevance: Most explicit statement regarding our core research question about combining vintages

quotes.quote: Net international migration plays an integral role in determining both the size and demographic composition of the population at the national level. It is the most complex determinant of population change, and its complete measurement involves the measurement of several sub-components, each one using separate methodology.
quotes.context: Introduction to 1990-2000 NIM measurement working paper
quotes.relevance: Establishes complexity of NIM estimation and multi-component nature from 2000s methodology

quotes.quote: In view of the fact that these sub-components are estimated separately, each is subject to differing levels of uncertainty or bias.
quotes.context: Discussion of uncertainty in NIM components
quotes.relevance: Documents acknowledged uncertainty in 2000s methodology

quotes.quote: Although the NIM component comprises approximately twelve percent of the total DA resident population under age 65, it represents a large portion of the uncertainty in the DA estimates.
quotes.context: Discussion of NIM's role in Demographic Analysis uncertainty
quotes.relevance: Quantifies disproportionate contribution of NIM to overall estimation uncertainty

quotes.quote: The largest share of uncertainty in the range of Demographic Analysis estimates, nearly 40%, comes from estimates of the foreign-born population. International migration of the native population accounts for around 10% of the variance of the range of estimates.
quotes.context: 2020 Demographic Analysis uncertainty breakdown
quotes.relevance: Quantifies NIM as source of ~40% of DA uncertainty

quotes.quote: Over the past decade, the Census Bureau undertook a major initiative to improve its ability to measure net international migration. The implementation of the American Community Survey (ACS) provides critical demographic information between decennial censuses that was not available in previous decades.
quotes.context: Introduction to 2010 DA NIM methodology paper
quotes.relevance: Documents the transition to ACS-based methodology as a major improvement over earlier methods

quotes.quote: In a residual technique, one or more identifiable components are subtracted from a comprehensive universe (such as the decennial census' total foreign-born population) yielding a residual estimate.
quotes.context: Explanation of residual methodology
quotes.relevance: Documents the residual method used in 2000s that differs from later ROYA method

quotes.quote: Because the estimate was derived from a residual methodology, any limitations in the methods or in the measurement of other migration components are reflected in the residual number.
quotes.context: Discussion of residual method limitations
quotes.relevance: Documents how residual method propagates errors from component estimates

quotes.quote: Previous studies indicate that the population size affects the accuracy of population projections. This is mainly due to the relationship between 'true demographic rates' (fertility, mortality, migration rates) and the population size.
quotes.context: Discussion of factors affecting projection accuracy
quotes.relevance: Documents that small population bases have less accurate demographic estimates

quotes.quote: Since the detailed demographic rates for small states will be likely to have many small numbers in each cell or many empty cells, these rates for smaller population bases will be unstable.
quotes.context: Explanation of why small states have less reliable estimates
quotes.relevance: Directly relevant to North Dakota as a small-population state

quotes.quote: The ACS sample was greatly reduced - one-third of the interviewed survey sample was lost - after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, which disproportionately affected certain groups and resulted in nonresponse bias in the estimates for the foreign born.
quotes.context: Discussion of COVID-19 impact on 2020 ACS data quality
quotes.relevance: Documents special data quality issues affecting 2020-2021 period estimates

quotes.quote: The data collection issues experienced by the 2020 ACS severely affected data quality, so the Census Bureau only released experimental estimates from the 1-year data.
quotes.context: Census Bureau response to 2020 ACS quality issues
quotes.relevance: Documents that 2020 data required special handling due to quality concerns

quotes.quote: There is no universal norm for producing intercensal estimates. The Census Bureau historically has used a method to produce intercensal estimates that was outlined by Prithwis Das Gupta in the early 1980s.
quotes.context: Introduction to 2000-2010 intercensal methodology
quotes.relevance: Documents the Das Gupta method used for intercensal adjustment

quotes.quote: The ACS is used to distribute recent immigrants but is not keeping up with changing patterns. Research is ongoing to improve allocation of new immigrants to the states and counties.
quotes.context: Statement about limitations of current state allocation method
quotes.relevance: Census Bureau acknowledges ongoing limitations in state-level allocation

quotes.quote: For July 1, 2021, to June 30, 2022, the bureau's Vintage 2024 estimate for net international migration was almost 1.7 million, an increase of 700,000 over the previous Vintage 2023 (and 2022) estimates for that year.
quotes.context: Quantification of Vintage 2024 revision magnitude
quotes.relevance: Provides concrete measure of how much estimates can change between vintages

quotes.quote: The Census Bureau asks questions about whether a person moved in the last year and where he or she lived 1 year ago to create statistics about where people are moving (to/from places within the United States and from foreign countries).
quotes.context: Explanation of ROYA methodology
quotes.relevance: Documents the survey-based approach used for post-2005 NIM estimation
